tags.name: alerting
tags.description: Alerting APIs enable you to create and manage rules and alerts.

post.summary: Create a rule with a random identifier
post.description: To create a rule, you must have `all` privileges for the appropriate Kibana features, depending on the `consumer` and `rule_type_id` of the rule you're creating. For example, you must have privileges for the **Management > Stack rules** feature, **Analytics > Discover** and **Machine Learning** features, **Observability** features, or **Security** features. If the rule has actions, you must also have `read` privileges for the **Management > Actions and Connectors** feature. This API supports both key- and token-based authentication. To use key-based authentication, create an API key in Kibana and use it in the header of the API call. To use token-based authentication, provide a username and password; an API key that matches the current privileges of the user is created automatically. In both cases, the API key is subsequently used for authorization when the rule runs.

401.description: Authorization information is missing or invalid.

get.description: You must have `read` privileges for the **Management > Stack Rules** feature or for at least one of the **Analytics > Discover**, **Analytics > Machine Learning**, **Observability**, or **Security** features.

alerting_framework_health.description: Three substates identify the health of the alerting framework: `decryption_health`, `execution_health`, and `read_health`.

decryption_health.description: The timestamp and status of the rule decryption.

execution_health.description: The timestamp and status of the rule run.

read_health.description: The timestamp and status of the rule reading events.

has_permanent_encryption_key.description: If `false`, the encrypted saved object plugin does not have a permanent encryption key.

is_sufficiently_secure.description: If `false`, security is enabled but TLS is not.

401.description: Authorization information is missing or invalid.

get.description: If you have `read` privileges for one or more Kibana features, the API response contains information about the appropriate rule types. For example, there are rule types associated with the **Management > Stack Rules** feature, **Analytics > Discover** and **Machine Learning** features, **Observability** features, and **Security** features. To get rule types associated with the **Stack Monitoring** feature, use the `monitoring_user` built-in role.

action_groups.description: An explicit list of groups for which the rule type can schedule actions, each with the action group's unique ID and human readable name. Rule actions validation uses this configuration to ensure that groups are valid.

action_variables.description: A list of action variables that the rule type makes available via context and state in action parameter templates, and a short human readable description. When you create a rule in Kibana, it uses this information to prompt you for these variables in action parameter editors.

alerts.description: Details for writing alerts as data documents for this rule type.

context.description: The namespace for this rule type.

dynamic.description: Indicates whether new fields are added dynamically.

isSpaceAware.description: Indicates whether the alerts are space-aware. If true, space-specific alert indices are used.

fieldMap.description: Mapping information for each field supported in alerts as data documents for this rule type. For more information about mapping parameters, refer to the Elasticsearch documentation.

secondaryAlias.description: A secondary alias. It is typically used to support the signals alias for detection rules.

shouldWrite.description: Indicates whether the rule should write out alerts as data.

useEcs.description: Indicates whether to include the ECS component template for the alerts.

useLegacyAlerts.description: Indicates whether to include the legacy component template for the alerts.

authorized_consumers.description: The list of the plugins IDs that have access to the rule type.

category.description: The rule category, which is used by features such as category-specific maintenance windows.

default_action_group_id.description: The default identifier for the rule type group.

does_set_recovery_context.description: Indicates whether the rule passes context variables to its recovery action.

enabled_in_license.description: Indicates whether the rule type is enabled or disabled based on the subscription.

has_alerts_mappings.description: Indicates whether the rule type has custom mappings for the alert data.

id.description: The unique identifier for the rule type.

is_exportable.description: Indicates whether the rule type is exportable in **Stack Management > Saved Objects**.

minimum_license_required.description: The subscriptions required to use the rule type.

name.description: The descriptive name of the rule type.

producer.description: An identifier for the application that produces this rule type.

recovery_action_group.description: An action group to use when an alert goes from an active state to an inactive one.

401.description: Authorization information is missing or invalid.

delete.description: Deprecated in 7.13.0. Use the delete rule API instead. WARNING: After you delete an alert, you cannot recover it.

parameters.name: alertId
parameters.description: The identifier for the alert.

401.description: Authorization information is missing or invalid.

get.description: Deprecated in 7.13.0. Use the get rule API instead.

parameters.name: alertId
parameters.description: The identifier for the alert.

401.description: Authorization information is missing or invalid.

post.description: Deprecated in 7.13.0. Use the create rule API instead.

parameters.name: alertId
parameters.description: An UUID v1 or v4 identifier for the alert. If this parameter is omitted, the identifier is randomly generated.

actionTypeId.description: The identifier for the action type.

group.description: Grouping actions is recommended for escalations for different types of alert instances. If you don't need this functionality, set it to `default`.

id.description: The ID of the action saved object.

params.description: The map to the `params` that the action type will receive. `params` are handled as Mustache templates and passed a default set of context.

alertTypeId.description: The ID of the alert type that you want to call when the alert is scheduled to run.

consumer.description: The name of the application that owns the alert. This name has to match the Kibana feature name, as that dictates the required role-based access control privileges.

enabled.description: Indicates if you want to run the alert on an interval basis after it is created.

name.description: A name to reference and search.

notifyWhen.description: The condition for throttling the notification.

params.description: The parameters to pass to the alert type executor `params` value. This will also validate against the alert type params validator, if defined.

schedule.description: The schedule specifying when this alert should be run. A schedule is structured such that the key specifies the format you wish to use and its value specifies the schedule.

interval.description: The interval format specifies the interval in seconds, minutes, hours or days at which the alert should run.

tags.description: A list of keywords to reference and search.

throttle.description: How often this alert should fire the same actions. This will prevent the alert from sending out the same notification over and over. For example, if an alert with a schedule of 1 minute stays in a triggered state for 90 minutes, setting a throttle of `10m` or `1h` will prevent it from sending 90 notifications during this period.

401.description: Authorization information is missing or invalid.

put.description: Deprecated in 7.13.0. Use the update rule API instead.

params.description: The map to the `params` that the action type will receive. `params` are handled as Mustache templates and passed a default set of context.

name.description: A name to reference and search.

notifyWhen.description: The condition for throttling the notification.

params.description: The parameters to pass to the alert type executor `params` value. This will also validate against the alert type params validator, if defined.

schedule.description: The schedule specifying when this alert should be run. A schedule is structured such that the key specifies the format you wish to use and its value specifies the schedule.

interval.description: The interval format specifies the interval in seconds, minutes, hours or days at which the alert should run.

tags.description: A list of keywords to reference and search.

throttle.description: How often this alert should fire the same actions. This will prevent the alert from sending out the same notification over and over. For example, if an alert with a schedule of 1 minute stays in a triggered state for 90 minutes, setting a throttle of `10m` or `1h` will prevent it from sending 90 notifications during this period.

get.summary: Get a paginated set of alerts
get.description: Deprecated in 7.13.0. Use the find rules API instead. NOTE: Alert `params` are stored as a flattened field type and analyzed as keywords. As alerts change in Kibana, the results on each page of the response also change. Use the find API for traditional paginated results, but avoid using it to export large amounts of data.

parameters.name: default_search_operator
parameters.description: The default operator to use for the `simple_query_string`.

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: The fields to return in the `attributes` key of the response.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description: A KQL string that you filter with an attribute from your saved object. It should look like `savedObjectType.attributes.title: "myTitle"`. However, if you used a direct attribute of a saved object, such as `updatedAt`, you must define your filter, for example, `savedObjectType.updatedAt > 2018-12-22`.

parameters.name: has_reference
parameters.description: Filters the rules that have a relation with the reference objects with a specific type and identifier.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number to return.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of alerts to return per page.

parameters.name: search
parameters.description: An Elasticsearch `simple_query_string` query that filters the alerts in the response.

parameters.name: search_fields
parameters.description: The fields to perform the `simple_query_string` parsed query against.

parameters.name: sort_field
parameters.description: Determines which field is used to sort the results. The field must exist in the `attributes` key of the response.

parameters.name: sort_order
parameters.description: Determines the sort order.

alertingFrameworkHealth.description: Three substates identify the health of the alerting framework: `decryptionHealth`, `executionHealth`, and `readHealth`.

actionGroups.description: An explicit list of groups for which the alert type can schedule actions, each with the action group's unique ID and human readable name. Alert actions validation uses this configuration to ensure that groups are valid.

actionVariables.description: A list of action variables that the alert type makes available via context and state in action parameter templates, and a short human readable description. The Alert UI will use this information to prompt users for these variables in action parameter editors.

authorizedConsumers.description: The list of the plugins IDs that have access to the alert type.

defaultActionGroupId.description: The default identifier for the alert type group.

enabledInLicense.description: Indicates whether the rule type is enabled based on the subscription.

id.description: The unique identifier for the alert type.

isExportable.description: Indicates whether the alert type is exportable in Saved Objects Management UI.

minimumLicenseRequired.description: The subscriptions required to use the alert type.

name.description: The descriptive name of the alert type.

producer.description: An identifier for the application that produces this alert type.

recoveryActionGroup.description: An action group to use when an alert instance goes from an active state to an inactive one. If it is not specified, the default recovered action group is used.

create_slo_burn_rate_rule_request.title: Create slo burn rate rule request
create_slo_burn_rate_rule_request.description: A rule that detects when the burn rate is above a defined threshold for two different lookback periods. The two periods are a long period and a short period that is 1/12th of the long period. For each lookback period, the burn rate is computed as the error rate divided by the error budget. When the burn rates for both periods surpass the threshold, an alert occurs.

rule_type_id.description: The ID of the rule type that you want to call when the rule is scheduled to run.

create_uptime_monitor_status_rule_reques.title: Create uptime monitor status rule request
create_uptime_monitor_status_rule_reques.description: A rule that detects monitor errors and outages.

rule_type_id.description: The ID of the rule type that you want to call when the rule is scheduled to run.

filter.description: A filter written in Elasticsearch Query Domain Specific Language (DSL) as defined in the `kbn-es-query` package.

notify_when_action.description: Indicates how often alerts generate actions. Valid values include: `onActionGroupChange`: Actions run when the alert status changes; `onActiveAlert`: Actions run when the alert becomes active and at each check interval while the rule conditions are met; `onThrottleInterval`: Actions run when the alert becomes active and at the interval specified in the throttle property while the rule conditions are met. NOTE: You cannot specify `notify_when` at both the rule and action level. The recommended method is to set it for each action. If you set it at the rule level then update the rule in Kibana, it is automatically changed to use action-specific values.

throttle_action.description: The throttle interval, which defines how often an alert generates repeated actions. It is specified in seconds, minutes, hours, or days and is applicable only if `notify_when` is set to `onThrottleInterval`. NOTE: You cannot specify the throttle interval at both the rule and action level. The recommended method is to set it for each action. If you set it at the rule level then update the rule in Kibana, it is automatically changed to use action-specific values.

items.description: An action that runs under defined conditions.

alerts_filter.description: Conditions that affect whether the action runs. If you specify multiple conditions, all conditions must be met for the action to run. For example, if an alert occurs within the specified time frame and matches the query, the action runs.

query.description: Defines a query filter that determines whether the action runs.

kql.description: A filter written in Kibana Query Language (KQL).

timeframe.description: Defines a period that limits whether the action runs.

days.description: Defines the days of the week that the action can run, represented as an array of numbers. For example, `1` represents Monday. An empty array is equivalent to specifying all the days of the week.

hours.description: Defines the range of time in a day that the action can run. If the `start` value is `00:00` and the `end` value is `24:00`, actions be generated all day.

end.description: The end of the time frame in 24-hour notation (`hh:mm`).

start.description: The start of the time frame in 24-hour notation (`hh:mm`).

timezone.description: The ISO time zone for the `hours` values. Values such as `UTC` and `UTC+1` also work but lack built-in daylight savings time support and are not recommended.

connector_type_id.description: The type of connector. This property appears in responses but cannot be set in requests.

frequency.description: The properties that affect how often actions are generated. If the rule type supports setting `summary` to `true`, the action can be a summary of alerts at the specified notification interval. Otherwise, an action runs for each alert at the specified notification interval. NOTE: You cannot specify these parameters when `notify_when` or `throttle` are defined at the rule level.

summary.description: Indicates whether the action is a summary.

group.description: The group name, which affects when the action runs (for example, when the threshold is met or when the alert is recovered). Each rule type has a list of valid action group names. If you don't need to group actions, set to `default`.

id.description: The identifier for the connector saved object.

params.description: The parameters for the action, which are sent to the connector. The `params` are handled as Mustache templates and passed a default set of context.

uuid.description: A universally unique identifier (UUID) for the action.

alert_delay.description: Indicates that an alert occurs only when the specified number of consecutive runs met the rule conditions.

active.description: The number of consecutive runs that must meet the rule conditions.

consumer.description: The name of the application or feature that owns the rule. For example: `alerts`, `apm`, `discover`, `infrastructure`, `logs`, `metrics`, `ml`, `monitoring`, `securitySolution`, `siem`, `stackAlerts`, or `uptime`.

enabled_rule.description: Indicates whether you want to run the rule on an interval basis after it is created.

name_rule.description: The name of the rule. While this name does not have to be unique, a distinctive name can help you identify a rule.

notify_when.description: Deprecated in 8.13.0. Use the `notify_when` property in the action `frequency` object instead. Indicates how often alerts generate actions. NOTE: You cannot specify `notify_when` at both the rule and action level. If you set it at the rule level then update the rule in Kibana, it is automatically changed to use action-specific values.

schedule.description: The check interval, which specifies how frequently the rule conditions are checked. The interval is specified in seconds, minutes, hours, or days.

throttle.description: Deprecated in 8.13.0. Use the `throttle` property in the action `frequency` object instead. The throttle interval, which defines how often an alert generates repeated actions. NOTE: You cannot specify the throttle interval at both the rule and action level. If you set it at the rule level then update the rule in Kibana, it is automatically changed to use action-specific values.

aggfield.description: The name of the numeric field that is used in the aggregation. This property is required when `aggType` is `avg`, `max`, `min` or `sum`.

aggtype.description: The type of aggregation to perform.

excludehitsfrompreviousrun.description: Indicates whether to exclude matches from previous runs. If `true`, you can avoid alert duplication by excluding documents that have already been detected by the previous rule run. This option is not available when a grouping field is specified.

groupby.description: Indicates whether the aggregation is applied over all documents (`all`) or split into groups (`top`) using a grouping field (`termField`). If grouping is used, an alert will be created for each group when it exceeds the threshold; only the top groups (up to `termSize` number of groups) are checked.

termsize.description: This property is required when `groupBy` is `top`. It specifies the number of groups to check against the threshold and therefore limits the number of alerts on high cardinality fields.

timefield.description: The field that is used to calculate the time window.

timewindowsize.description: The size of the time window (in `timeWindowUnit` units), which determines how far back to search for documents. Generally it should be a value higher than the rule check interval to avoid gaps in detection.

timewindowunit.description: The type of units for the time window: seconds, minutes, hours, or days.

size.description: The number of documents to pass to the configured actions when the threshold condition is met.

termfield.description: The names of up to four fields that are used for grouping the aggregation. This property is required when `groupBy` is `top`.

threshold.description: The threshold value that is used with the `thresholdComparator`. If the `thresholdComparator` is `between` or `notBetween`, you must specify the boundary values.

thresholdcomparator.description: The comparison function for the threshold. For example, "is above", "is above or equals", "is below", "is below or equals", "is between", and "is not between".

oneOf.description: The parameters for an Elasticsearch query rule that uses ES|QL to define the query. This functionality is in technical pre view and may be changed or removed in a future release. Elastic will work to fix any issues, but features in technical preview are not subject to the support SLA of official GA features.

esql.description: The query definition, which uses Elasticsearch Query Language.

searchType.description: The type of query, in this case a query that uses Elasticsearch Query Language (ES|QL).

size.description: When `searchType` is `esqlQuery`, this property is required but it does not affect the rule behavior.

threshold.description: The threshold value that is used with the `thresholdComparator`. When `searchType` is `esqlQuery`, this property is required and must be set to zero.

thresholdComparator.description: The comparison function for the threshold. When `searchType` is `esqlQuery`, this property is required and must be set to ">". Since the `threshold` value must be `0`, the result is that an alert occurs whenever the query returns results.

oneOf.description: The parameters for an Elasticsearch query rule that uses KQL or Lucene to define the query.

searchConfiguration.description: The query definition, which uses KQL or Lucene to fetch the documents from Elasticsearch.

searchType.description: The type of query, in this case a text-based query that uses KQL or Lucene.

oneOf.description: The parameters for an Elasticsearch query rule that uses Elasticsearch Query DSL to define the query.

esQuery.description: The query definition, which uses Elasticsearch Query DSL.

searchType.description: The type of query, in this case a query that uses Elasticsearch Query DSL.

params_index_threshold_rule.description: The parameters for an index threshold rule.

filterKuery.description: A KQL expression thats limits the scope of alerts.

sloId.description: The SLO identifier used by the rule

burnRateThreshold.description: The burn rate threshold used to trigger the alert

maxBurnRateThreshold.description: The maximum burn rate threshold value defined by the SLO error budget

longWindow.description: The duration of the long window used to compute the burn rate

shortWindow.description: The duration of the short window used to compute the burn rate

create_rule_request.title: Create rule request body properties
create_rule_request.description: The properties vary depending on the rule type.

api_key_created_by_user.description: Indicates whether the API key that is associated with the rule was created by the user.

api_key_owner.description: The owner of the API key that is associated with the rule and used to run background tasks.

consumer.description: The application or feature that owns the rule. For example, `alerts`, `apm`, `discover`, `infrastructure`, `logs`, `metrics`, `ml`, `monitoring`, `securitySolution`, `siem`, `stackAlerts`, or `uptime`.

created_at.description: The date and time that the rule was created.

created_by.description: The identifier for the user that created the rule.

enabled.description: Indicates whether the rule is currently enabled.

notify_when.description: Indicates how often alerts generate actions.

params.description: The parameters for the rule.

rule_type_id.description: The identifier for the type of rule. For example, `.es-query`, `.index-threshold`, `logs.alert.document.count`, `monitoring_alert_cluster_health`, `siem.thresholdRule`, or `xpack.ml.anomaly_detection_alert`.

running.description: Indicates whether the rule is running.

updated_at.description: The date and time that the rule was updated most recently.

updated_by.description: The identifier for the user that updated this rule most recently.

fieldmap_properties.title: Field map objects in the get rule types response

array.description: Indicates whether the field is an array.

dynamic.description: Indicates whether it is a dynamic field mapping.

format.description: Indicates the format of the field. For example, if the `type` is `date_range`, the `format` can be `epoch_millis||strict_date_optional_time`.

ignore_above.description: Specifies the maximum length of a string field. Longer strings are not indexed or stored.

index.description: Indicates whether field values are indexed.

properties.description: Details about the object properties. This property is applicable when `type` is `object`.

type.description: The data type for each object property.

required.description: Indicates whether the field is required.

scaling_factor.description: The scaling factor to use when encoding values. This property is applicable when `type` is `scaled_float`. Values will be multiplied by this factor at index time and rounded to the closest long value.

type.description: Specifies the data type for the field.

createdAt.description: The date and time that the alert was created.

createdBy.description: The identifier for the user that created the alert.

enabled.description: Indicates whether the alert is currently enabled.

updatedBy.description: The identifier for the user that updated this alert most recently.

create_es_query_esql_rule_request.summary: Create an Elasticsearch query rule that uses Elasticsearch Query Language (ES|QL).

esqlQuery.esql: FROM kibana_sample_data_logs | KEEP bytes, clientip, host, geo.dest | where geo.dest != "GB" | STATS sumbytes = sum(bytes) by clientip, host | WHERE sumbytes > 5000 | SORT sumbytes desc | LIMIT 10

params.message:
Elasticsearch query rule '{{rule.name}}' is active:
- Value: {{context.value}} - Conditions Met: {{context.conditions}} over {{rule.params.timeWindowSize}}{{rule.params.timeWindowUnit}} - Timestamp: {{context.date}} - Link: {{context.link}}

create_es_query_rule_request.summary: Create an Elasticsearch query rule that uses Elasticsearch query domain specific language (DSL) to define its query and a server log connector to send notifications.

params.message: The system has detected {{alerts.new.count}} new, {{alerts.ongoing.count}} ongoing, and {{alerts.recovered.count}} recovered alerts.

create_es_query_kql_rule_request.summary: Create an Elasticsearch query rule that uses Kibana query language (KQL).

create_es_query_esql_rule_response.summary: The create rule API returns a JSON object that contains details about the rule.

params.message:
Elasticsearch query rule '{{rule.name}}' is active:
- Value: {{context.value}} - Conditions Met: {{context.conditions}} over {{rule.params.timeWindowSize}}{{rule.params.timeWindowUnit}} - Timestamp: {{context.date}} - Link: {{context.link}}

esqlQuery.esql: FROM kibana_sample_data_logs | keep bytes, clientip, host, geo.dest | WHERE geo.dest != "GB" | stats sumbytes = sum(bytes) by clientip, host | WHERE sumbytes > 5000 | sort sumbytes desc | limit 10

create_es_query_rule_response.summary: The create rule API returns a JSON object that contains details about the rule.

params.message: The system has detected {{alerts.new.count}} new, {{alerts.ongoing.count}} ongoing, and {{alerts.recovered.count}} recovered alerts.

create_es_query_kql_rule_response.summary: The create rule API returns a JSON object that contains details about the rule.

create_index_threshold_rule_response.summary: The create rule API returns a JSON object that contains details about the rule.

create_tracking_containment_rule_respons.summary: The create rule API returns a JSON object that contains details about the rule.

get_health_response.summary: Retrieve information about the health of the alerting framework.

get_rule_types_response.summary: Retrieve rule types associated with Kibana machine learning features

context.name: timestamp
context.description: The bucket timestamp of the anomaly

context.name: timestampIso8601
context.description: The bucket time of the anomaly in ISO8601 format

context.name: jobIds
context.description: List of job IDs that triggered the alert

context.name: isInterim
context.description: Indicate if top hits contain interim results

context.name: score
context.description: Anomaly score at the time of the notification action

context.name: anomalyExplorerUrl
context.description: URL to open in the Anomaly Explorer
